awd_titl_txt: RAIN - Rural Activation and Innovation Network
awd_abstract_narration:
Rural communities across the Nation are, in general, underserved in terms of the various forms of STEM education. Clearly, they are under-represented in the realm of contemporary STEM subjects often because they are geographically isolated and cannot travel to cities where there are Science and Museum Centers for informal education opportunities. As part of its overall strategy to enhance learning in informal environments, the Advancing Informal STEM Learning (AISL) program funds innovative resources for use in a variety of settings. This award will, in a collaborative effort within the community, bring STEM activities to selected communities in Arizona. Among the initial activities, there will be a STEM festival highlighting aspects of the community and its assets in an effort to gather support and begin to give perspective on identity for an extended effort of longevity. Further, these communities will be networked to facilitate discussion and to enhance effectiveness. 

This project will develop STEM activities and STEM learning within a selected community by giving the community and its residents identity and opportunities for youth development and career choices. The selected communities in Arizona represent a diverse group that includes Native Americans and Latinos. In collaboration with community residents, a designed plan will be established that satisfies the needs and opportunities that can be derived from the extant community assets whether it is mining, tourism, or government facilities. Evaluation efforts are set to determine what the key features and methodologies are that facilitate STEM knowledge acquisition for each rural community. This project represents seminal and foundational work in the area of rural informal STEM education. Researchers will explore the following questions: 1) understanding how rural communities currently perceive, access, and engage in informal science learning, and the extent to which they identify themselves and/or their community in relation to science; and 2) the extent to which relevant, place-based networks can increase public awareness of local STEM assets, resources, and opportunities, and foster a science-related identity at both the personal and community level. These data will be compared to data on other rural community projects in the AISL portfolio. The partners in this effort include the Arizona Science Center, community leaders from four rural regions in Arizona, Arizona State University, and the Center of Science and Industry.
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
After observing an 8th-grade classroom in a remote rural school in northeastern Arizona, the RAIN program manager realized that youth and communities far removed from urban resources were just as capable and interested in STEM and the future as any city dweller. However, they lacked the resources, experienced support, and an understanding of what was available. That was the impetus behind the Rural Activation and Innovation Network (RAIN). 

RAIN was developed to study and begin the conversation around place-based STEM Learning capacity by empowering rural and remote communities to see themselves in the pictures of scientists, researchers, and innovators. The proposal for RAIN began in 2009 and was funded in 2016 by NSF as an AISL project to provide foundational research. Due to COVID, the project was able to extend its impact through 2023. 

At its heart, RAIN helped build capacity, supported innovators, and developed economic pathways imbued with local voice and choice. The project team chose to use an existing model created by Arizona’s Early Childhood Health and Education Board (Arizona First Things First) - regional councils empowered to channel funds and support based on local needs. While research showed that many of the needs within Arizona's rural and remote communities are shared, there were also unique differences between the regions. Regions include a partial (Verde Valley of Yavapai County), single (Cochise County), and two-county block (Graham/Greenlee, Southern Navajo/Apache Counties). The smallest region covers almost 750 square miles, while the largest over 10,000 square miles. Regions mainly run along the five eastern counties from the Mexican border to Interstate 40. This area includes border, agricultural, ranching, forests, and high desert ecosystems with demographics as varied as the environments. 

Four Rural Innovation Councils (RICs) drew members from multiple sectors to lead the effort in each region. RIC members represented K12, Higher Education, local Non-Profits, Healthcare, Elected Officials, First Things First Regional Directors, parents, and retirees. Each RIC created a strategic plan that included goals, objectives, funding protocols, and membership expectations. They also focused on sustainability to ensure the project continued beyond NSF funding, as their work was critical to the vitality of their communities. 

Over the six-year project, Regional Innovation Councils (RICs) supported 175 local, place-based projects, convened over 250 meetings with community members and stakeholders, enabled the formation of 3 new STEM nonprofits, and established collaborations with STEM Learning organizations nationwide. The project team estimates that the project directly impacted well over 100,000 individuals. 

While the project was successful, it was not always easy, and there were setbacks. The latter of which universally revolved around expectations. For some, it was the open-ended nature of the project. For instance, those used to working on grant-funded projects expected clear actions outlined. However, the project was designed to allow each region to co-develop its ecosystem. It took time for many RIC members to embrace the freedom to make decisions based on local needs, not those of a funder. Others realized that they needed time to cultivate and build relationships. The researchers took these observations and used them to create a greater understanding of how to blend STEM learning and opportunities into rural and remote communities. Findings found a heavy reliance upon relation networks, authenticity, and place-based focus. 

Halfway through the RAIN project, RICs began to strategize about sustainability. At the project’s sunset, two of the four regions adapted, reformed, and expanded their goals.  A third RIC merged with a regional non-profit, and the fourth reverted to a group associated with STEM outreach through a community college. The cornerstone for each group was that they were all administered locally, had local backbone organizations, and expanded their membership to include sectors outside of the RAIN protocols. 

RAIN sought to study how to empower rural and remote communities and support them in developing STEM learning opportunities that meet the changing demands of today's workforce. The project created three new businesses, built hundreds of relationships between individuals and statewide and national organizations, established new festivals, and sustained STEM programs. Importantly, communities typically not included in the STEM Learning Ecosystem mainstream began to see themselves included in discussions that were not part of their historic interactions.

 

 


Last Modified: 11/27/2023
Modified by: Jeremy R Babendure
